DOC.HEAD: Light Icing of Wings Reported Before Crash That Killed Six
DOC.TEXT: De-icing equipment and other parts of a commuter plane that will be tested in an effort to find the cause of a crash that killed all six people aboard the plane. The crew of the United Express plane from Seattle reported light icing about an hour before it crashed at a small airport 180 miles southeast of Seattle, Barry Trotter of the National Transportation Safety Board said Thursday. De-icing and other equipment was being checked, but it is much too early to determine the cause of the accident Tuesday, Trotter said. ``We still have not discounted anything and we are still looking at everything,'' he said at a news conference. The British Aerospace Jetstream 31 slammed into a sagebrush field short of the runway and burst into flames, killing two crew members and four passengers. ``Several other aircraft that had landed (prior to the crash) reported light icing to insignificant icing,'' Trotter said. ``An hour and 15 minutes before the accident, this aircraft reported light icing.'' But he said the crew didn't report any trouble in its final communication with the airport control tower or the FAA control center in Seattle just minutes before the plane went down. Icing tends to slow a plane's forward speed or force it downward by increasing aircraft weight and drag and reducing lift and thrust. The plane had made 7,161 flights before to the crash and its flight history and maintenance records appeared clean, Trotter said. United Express _ one of several similarly named commuter airlines around the country _ is based in Pasco and serves 15 cities in Washington, Oregon, Idaho and Montana. It serves as a feeder airline for United Airlines, with which it has a marketing agreement that permits it to use United's computer system and logo. United Express, operated by NPA Inc., began commercial air service in July 1987. Killed in the crash were the two crew members, Capt. Barry ``Will'' Roberts, 38, the pilot, and First Officer Doug McInroe, 25, the copilot, both of Kennewick; and passengers Kim Shewmaker, 34, also a United Express pilot who has a home in Kimberly, Idaho, and an apartment in Richland; Rey Resendez, 46, of Duncanville, Texas; Wayne Kingry, 42, of Denver; and Elliott Fischer, 56, of Seal Beach, Calif., who recently moved to Richland.
